abstract: Yahoo’s board and management earned a reprieve after a weekend deal ended a bruising and acrimonious fight for control of the company with Carl C. Icahn.
snippet: Yahoo’s board and management earned a reprieve after a weekend deal ended a bruising and acrimonious fight for control of the company with Carl C. Icahn.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo’s board and management earned a reprieve after a weekend deal ended a bruising and acrimonious fight for control of the company with Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor.

headline.main: Yahoo Deal Wards Off Proxy Fight
headline.print_headline: Yahoo Deal Wards Off Proxy Fight

abstract: Looks Like Yahoo has figured out how to neuter Carl Icahn — kill him with kindness. That would seem to be the lesson emerging from Monday’s announcement that the 77-year-old shareholder activist, along with Jonathan Miller, who used to run Time Warner’s AOL division, will be joining the Yahoo board. It seems pretty likely that Icahn was about to lose his proxy fight — and that both he and Yahoo knew it. (It didn’t help Icahn that a big Yahoo shareholder Bill Miller of Legg Mason decided to side with Yahoo management, despite his annoyance that Yahoo didn’t sell to Microsoft.)
lead_paragraph: Looks Like Yahoo has figured out how to neuter Carl Icahn — kill him with kindness. That would seem to be the lesson emerging from Monday’s announcement that the 77-year-old shareholder activist, along with Jonathan Miller, who used to run Time Warner’s AOL division, will be joining the Yahoo board. It seems pretty likely that Icahn was about to lose his proxy fight — and that both he and Yahoo knew it. (It didn’t help Icahn that a big Yahoo shareholder Bill Miller of Legg Mason decided to side with Yahoo management, despite his annoyance that Yahoo didn’t sell to Microsoft.)

abstract: Microsoft is said to be starting an expensive campaign to reassure consumers that its Vista operating system isn’t all that bad.
snippet: Microsoft is said to be starting an expensive campaign to reassure consumers that its Vista operating system isn’t all that bad.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is really taking the gloves off this time. ZDNet is reporting that it will spend $500 million to make a powerful statement to its hundreds of millions of customers. I imagine the statement would have to go something like this:
